case_vignette: a 30-year-old male presents for evaluation of a dark discoloration on the posterior thighs present for the past month. he denies any topical products applied to the area. he denies any pain or pruritus at the area. he has not tried any treatments. the rash has been stable in size, is constant, and is not significantly growing in size. he works a desk job and reports sitting on a seat warmer over the past several years. physical examination reveals reticulated lacy brown patches on the posterior thighs and lower buttocks.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a dark discoloration on the back of my thighs that has been there for about a month.
Have you noticed any changes in the texture of the skin in that area, such as thickening or roughness?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in the texture of the skin in that area.
Have you experienced any itching or irritation in the area of discoloration?
No, I haven't experienced any itching or irritation in the area of discoloration.
Do you have any known allergies or other medical conditions that might be relevant?
I haven't mentioned any known allergies or other medical conditions that might be relevant.
Have you been exposed to any new skincare products, chemicals, or environmental factors that could have affected that area?
No, I haven't used any new skincare products or been exposed to different chemicals or environmental factors that could have affected that area.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin issues or any known genetic skin conditions?
I haven't mentioned any family history of similar skin issues or known genetic skin conditions.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 30-year-old male.
Final Diagnosis: Erythema dyschromicum perstans (Ashy dermatosis)
